facts.text: Applicant Sawal Das tried together with father Jamuna Prasad and step-mother Kalawati Devi for murder of his wife Chanda Devi, alleged frequent quarrels with Kalawati.
Applicant, father and others charged under Section 201 IPC for disposing of body of Chanda Devi knowing she had been murdered.

Trial Court convicted Sawal Das, Jamuna Prasad and Kalawati under Section 302/34 IPC, sentenced each to rigorous imprisonment for life; convicted applicant and father under Section 201 IPC but no separate sentences imposed.

High Court set aside convictions of Kalawati for both offences, ordered her at liberty; set aside Jamuna Prasad's conviction under 302/34 but maintained under Section 201 IPC with 3 years RI; converted Sawal Das's conviction from 302/34 to 302 IPC simpliciter, maintained life imprisonment and conviction/sentence under Section 201 IPC to run concurrently.
High Court erroneously assumed Trial Court had sentenced Sawal Das separately under Section 201 IPC.

Supreme Court dismissed Jamuna Prasad's application for leave to appeal against conviction under Section 201 IPC; refused leave to Sawal Das to contest beyond correctness of conviction under Section 302 IPC.

Supreme Court considered uncertainties in facts as to who committed murder, gave benefit to Sawal Das as Section 34 failed; set aside his conviction under Section 302 IPC but affirmed under Section 201 IPC; murder committed after accused seen following Chanda Devi into room.
No special leave granted against Sawal Das's conviction under Section 201 IPC; some argument heard on appropriate sentence under Section 201 IPC.
Supreme Court imposed sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine under Section 201 IPC on Sawal Das.

legal_issues.text: Whether this Court can pass a sentence under Section 201 IPC when no separate sentence was imposed by Trial Court or specified by High Court, absent appeal by State.
Whether failure to pass separate sentence under Section 201 IPC by Trial Court, and High Court's assumption of sentence, prevents Supreme Court from imposing one.

petitioner_arguments.text: No appeal filed by State against Trial Court's failure to pass separate sentence under Section 201 IPC or High Court's failure to specify sentence; thus Supreme Court cannot pass any sentence under Section 201 IPC.
Applicant not heard on question of sentence under Section 201 IPC.

court_reasoning.text: Court has power to impose sentence on conviction even if not done by lower courts; sequential and incidental order under Section 423(1)(d) CrPC when affirming conviction without sentence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law does not envisage conviction without sentence; appellate court can pass just and proper consequential order.

court_reasoning.text: High Court orders showed sentence under Section 201 to run concurrently with life sentence, though period not fixed; upon setting aside 302 conviction, period for 201 had to be fixed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applicant was convicted and sentence ordered concurrent, only period unspecified.

court_reasoning.text: Applicant was heard on sentence; no sufficient grounds to revise 7 years RI and fine.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Re-heard on review after notice to State.

holdings.text: Supreme Court has power to pass sentence under Section 201 IPC as consequential to affirming conviction, even if lower courts failed to impose one.
Sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine under Section 201 IPC maintained.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayaram Vithoba Anr. v. The State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Court must impose sentence on conviction; appellate court can pass consequential sentence under Section 423(1)(d) CrPC when affirming conviction without sentence.
View that such order enhances sentence disagreed with.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions and sentences under these sections; separate sentence required for each offence even if concurrent.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellate court power to make consequential or incidental orders just and proper, including imposing sentence on affirmed conviction.

outcome.summary: Review petition dismissed; sentence of 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine under Section 201 IPC confirmed, no grounds to revise.

key_quotes.text: "When a person is tried for an offence and convicted, it is the duty of the Court to impose on him such sentence, as is prescribed therefor. The law does not envisage a person being convicted for an offence without a sentence being imposed therefor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes duty to sentence on conviction, basis for appellate power.

key_quotes.text: "The power to pass a sentence under those circumstances is derived from the law which enacts that on conviction a sentence shall be imposed on the accused, and that is a power which can and ought to be exercised by all the Courts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies Supreme Court's authority to impose sentence.
